original_data.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with an unsteady and broad-based gait, dysmetria, and intention tremor in the distal upper extremities. Her past medical history is relevant for depression, personality changes, and declining work performance, for which she has been put on leave from her current job as an elementary school teacher. On physical examination, patient has dysarthria, dystonia, and an ataxic gait. Ophthalmologic examination reveals multi-colored irises with concentric rings around the periphery (findings shown in the photo). Sensation and motor functions are preserved. Which of the following would you expect to be abnormally accumulated in this patient’s tissues?

model_response:
The clinical findings are most consistent with Wilsons’ disease (hepatolenticular degeneration), an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by abnormal copper accumulation in tissues, particularly the liver and brain. The disease has a variable presentation, with hepatic involvement often preceding neurologic symptoms. Hepatic involvement leads to cirrhosis, hepatitis, or hepatic decompensation. Neurologic symptoms include dystonia, incoordination, tremor, and behavioral abnormalities. Kayser-Fleischer rings (KF rings) are seen in the iris due to copper deposition in Descemet membrane in the eye. Diagnosis is made by the measurement of copper levels in the 24-hour urine sample.

Option A: Iron overload can lead to cirrhosis, but the presentation is different.
Option B: Copper accumulation can occur in Wilson’s disease, but it is not associated with the multi-colored iris findings.
Option C: Lead poisoning can cause neurologic symptoms, but it is not associated with the multi-colored iris findings.
Option D: Mercury poisoning can cause neurologic symptoms, but it is not associated with the multi-colored iris findings.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
An abnormal gait pattern in which persons stand and walk with their feet spaced widely apart. This is often a component of cerebellar ataxia. [HPO:curators]
Lack of coordination of movement necessary to execute a smooth action; often the person over reaches or under reaches. This condition is sometimes symptomatic of a cerebellar cognitive dysfunction.
A tremor that occurs with the voluntary movement of a muscle. Subcategories include postural, kinetic, and isometric tremors.
Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.
The region of the upper limb in animals, extending from the deltoid region to the HAND, and including the ARM; AXILLA; and SHOULDER.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
Depressive states usually of moderate intensity in contrast with MAJOR DEPRESSIVE DISORDER present in neurotic and psychotic disorders.
A noticeable change in a person's behavior and thinking. Causes include depression, drug or alcohol abuse, brain injuries, brain tumors, and Alzheimer's disease.
Measure of how well someone performs given tasks at their place of work.
The act of leaving a destination.
Crafts, trades, professions, or other means of earning a living.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.

Disorders of speech articulation caused by imperfect coordination of pharynx, larynx, tongue, or face muscles. This may result from CRANIAL NERVE DISEASES; NEUROMUSCULAR DISEASES; CEREBELLAR DISEASES; BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES; BRAIN STEM diseases; or diseases of the corticobulbar tracts (see PYRAMIDAL TRACTS). The cortical language centers are intact in this condition. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p489)

An attitude or posture due to the co-contraction of agonists and antagonist muscles in one region of the body. It most often affects the large axial muscles of the trunk and limb girdles. Conditions which feature persistent or recurrent episodes of dystonia as a primary manifestation of disease are referred to as DYSTONIC DISORDERS. (Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p77)

Impairment of the ability to coordinate the movements required for normal ambulation (WALKING) which may result from impairments of motor function or sensory feedback. This condition may be associated with BRAIN DISEASES (including CEREBELLAR DISEASES and BASAL GANGLIA DISEASES); SPINAL CORD DISEASES; or PERIPHERAL NERVOUS SYSTEM DISEASES.
A test performed by an ophthalmologist or optometrist assessing vision and ability to focus on and discern objects, as well as other tests and examinations pertaining to the eyes.
The part of a cell encompassing the cell cortex, the plasma membrane, and any external encapsulating structures. [GOC:mah]

Discrete concentrations of energy, apparently massless elementary particles, that move at the speed of light. They are the unit or quantum of electromagnetic radiation. Photons are emitted when electrons move from one energy state to another. (From Hawley's Condensed Chemical Dictionary, 11th ed)

The process in which specialized SENSORY RECEPTOR CELLS transduce peripheral stimuli (physical or chemical) into NERVE IMPULSES which are then transmitted to the various sensory centers in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM.

The result for a quantitative observation is above the upper limit of the reference range (as defined for the respective test procedure).

Synonym: Above high normal
A state characterized by the gradual increase in entities or substances.

Collections of differentiated CELLS, such as EPITHELIUM; CONNECTIVE TISSUE; MUSCLES; and NERVE TISSUE. Tissues are cooperatively arranged to form organs with specialized functions such as RESPIRATION; DIGESTION; REPRODUCTION; MOVEMENT; and others.
